definition:
A propositional formula is a DNF formula, meaning Disjunctive Normal
Form, if it is a disjunction of conjunctions of literals (a literal is a
propositional variable or its negation). Hence, a DNF is a formula of
the form: $K_1 \vee K_2 \vee \ldots \vee K_n$, where each $K_i$ is of
the form $l_{i1} \wedge l_{i2} \wedge \ldots \wedge l_{im}$ for literals
$l_{ij}$ and some $m$ which can vary for each $K_i$.

Example:
$(x\wedge  y \wedge \neg z) \vee (y\wedge \neg w \wedge \neg u) \vee (x \wedge v)$.
